data.title: Charley Walters: Lakers want to trade Andrew Bynum, not Pau Gasol, to Timberwolves
data.meta_description: A little birdie says the Los Angeles Lakers have changed their mind about trying to trade Pau Gasol to the Timberwolves and that they’re looking to peddle Andrew Bynum instead. The Wolves are not interested in Bynum.Not many noticed, but when outfielder Bryce Harper, 19, pinch-hit for the National League in Tuesday night’s All-Star Game […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

A little birdie says the Los Angeles Lakers have changed their mind about trying to trade Pau Gasol to the Timberwolves and that they’re looking to peddle Andrew Bynum instead. The Wolves are not interested in Bynum.

Not many noticed, but when outfielder Bryce Harper, 19, pinch-hit for the National League in Tuesday night’s All-Star Game in Kansas City, Mo., former Twins catcher Butch Wynegar‘s 36-year-old record as the youngest position player to appear in the All-Star Game was broken.

Wynegar, at age 20, pinch-hit for the American League in the 1976 game in Philadelphia.

“I pinch-hit and walked off John ‘The Count’ Montefusco,” Wynegar said Wednesday, July 11.

“Well, records are meant to be broken, that’s how I look at it. It was nice to have it for 36 years, but that’s a pretty good guy in Bryce Harper to go ahead and break it.”

Wynegar, 56, is hitting coach for the New York Yankees’ Triple-A club — the Empire State Yankees — that this season is temporarily based in Rochester, N.Y.

“We’re doing a lot of traveling and living out of suitcases,” he said.

Wynegar spent six seasons with the Twins. For four seasons, he was major league hitting coach for the Milwaukee Brewers. He wants to return to the major leagues.

“Like players, we all don’t want to be in Triple-A, we want to be in the big leagues,” Wynegar said. “It’s really come down to who you know nowadays. I’ve had about five or six interviews since I left Milwaukee, and it seems I come in second every time to someone that the GM knows a little bit better.

“I just look at it as there’s a plan for me, and if it happens, it happens. If not, I enjoy what I’m doing now.”

Former Twins pitcher Pedro Ramos, 77, resides in Nicaragua and is doing fine, former teammate Camilo Pascual said.

Former Gopher Ralph Sampson III is with the Michael Jordan-owned Charlotte Bobcats’ Las Vegas summer league team.

Ben Utecht starred in football at Hastings High School, then for the Gophers, then played in a Super Bowl for the Indianapolis Colts, then recorded music in Nashville and went on national tour as a singing balladeer.

Now, maybe, we’ll be see him in the movies.

Utecht, a 1999 Hastings grad, is the lead actor in a short film, “Three Weeks,” about a guy who walked away from professional football to be a musician. Filming was completed two weeks ago. Plans are to release and promote it at major film festivals, including Sundance, beginning in September.

“We’ll see what happens,” Utecht said.

The 6-foot-6 Utecht, 31, played for the Colts during their 2006 championship season that ended with a 29-17 victory over Chicago in the 2007 Super Bowl.

“When I was playing football, I sought out professional voice lessons and acting lessons just to always be ready and prepared for anything that potentially could come my way,” he said. “Needless to say, I was ready for this and excited for the chance.”

Meanwhile, Utecht continues to talk with some New York music labels about his singing career. He already has released one album, “Christmas Hope.”

Utecht, who resides in Lakeville, was in the NFL for six seasons — four with Indianapolis, two with Cincinnati. He was forced to retire in 2009 because of repeated concussions.

John Williams, the beloved former Gophers offensive lineman who was a dentist in Minneapolis and died unexpectedly at age 64 last week, will be inducted into the “M” Club Hall of Fame on Sept. 20 at TCF Bank Stadium.

Former University of St. Thomas football star Fritz Waldvogel had a career-best 403 all-purpose yards to lead his first-place Schwabisch Hall Unicorns team to a 70-39 victory over the Franken Knights on Saturday in the 16-team German Football League.

The 5-foot-8 Waldvogel had 253 receiving yards as well as an 89-yard kickoff return among his three touchdowns. In five games for the Unicorns, Waldvogel has 15 TDs and 1,301 all-purpose yards.

DON’T PRINT THAT

One Minneapolis fan got into Monday’s All-Star Home Run Derby in Kansas City by buying a ticket off the street for $75 (face value $150). And he bought a lower-level ticket for Tuesday’s All-Star Game for $220 (face value $250).

But two other guys, just before Tuesday’s game, had to pay $380 apiece for lower-level seats.

It will be interesting whether baseball Commissioner Bud Selig, who is expected to be at Target Field on July 31 to officially welcome the Major League Reviving Baseball in Inner Cities (RBI) tournament, announces that the Twins will host the 2014 All-Star Game. If so, those tickets are expected to exceed the prices in Kansas City.

The Twins would love to host the 2014 game so they can begin leveraging 2013 and 2014 season-ticket sales for All-Star Game priority sales.

OVERHEARD

Former North Stars president Lou Nanne, who took Mike Modano with the No. 1 overall pick in the 1988 NHL draft, on Modano’s election Wednesday to the U.S. Hockey Hall of Fame: “Very appropriate. And when he’s eligible, he’ll make the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto, too.”

Originally Published: July 10, 2012 at 11:01 p.m.
